doc.title: Steel: Waiting for a demand inflection

- In spite of supportive (albeit perceived insufficient) trade measures and brightening prospects of defence/infrastructure spending, demand conditions have remained lacklustre in Europe.- We remain sceptical of the sustainability of the EU HRC rally, given the persistently weak demand backdrop.- We maintain our ‘In-Line’ industry view. Steel equities have re-rated sharply, with shares running ahead of fundamentals, especially for thyssenkrupp and Salzgitter, diminishing their risk-reward appeal. Our relative pick remains voestalpine (OW) as it still offers scope for more upside, has manageable decarbonisation investments, and exposure to end markets that benefit from an expansive infrastructure stimulus in Europe.

- Stainless demand remains lacklustre and will likely trail any rebound in carbon steel due to its later-cycle nature. We see no inflection in 2025, given poor demand, which will be further weighed on given global growth concerns, with EU/US spreads still below historical average levels.- While the sector remains cheap, trading at a \(\sim 34\%\) discount to its historical average on EV/normalised EBITDA, we still anticipate consensus earnings downgrades for 2025. Our relative preference is for Acerinox (OW), as its US/alloys exposure underpins its better earnings resilience.
Carbon Steel – Most preferred: ArcelorMittal and voestalpine

CompanyRating & PTKey pointsArcelorMittalEW €30.00Although the long-term investment case remains intact, the swift re-rating in ArcelorMittal shares is out of sync with the earnings impact from any potential Ukraine rebuild. The near-term risk-reward profile has become more balanced, in our view, warranting an Equal-weight rating.voestalpineONE STEP AHEAD.OW €25.60In contrast to peers, voestalpine's EBITDA/t has remained relatively resilient in the current downturn.The company has manageable decarbonisation investments/execution risks, minimising free cash flow burn versus peers.The company has exposure to end markets that may benefit from a more expansive infrastructure stimulus in Europe.SSABEW SEK61.00We maintain our Equal-weight rating but see downside risks to SSAB's valuation multiples in light of its extensive decarbonisation spending programme and pressured FCF. We will see whether the new CEO will shift strategy. Valuation is undemanding, with the shares trading on an EV/normalised EBITDA below their historical average.thyssenkruppUW €7.60UW €15.60UW TL 19.00thyssenkrupp shares have more than doubled YTD, with EV/NTM consensus EBITDA has re-rated by >50%, driven by heightened market optimism around Germany's defence and infrastructure revenue exposureAgainst that backdrop, our SotP suggests the shares are now trading at a 20-30% premium to their SotP, but unlocking value from portfolio simplification retains substantial execution riskThe underlying business continues to suffer from elevated cash needs vs its EBITDA potentialWhile the external demand environment may be improving, we argue that a meaningful reduction in costs and/or an uplift in the business' earnings power are needed to reduce cash leakageSALZGITTERAGStahl und TechnologieSalzgitter's cash burn is likely to intensify, given the need to spend on decarbonisation initiatives, while we feel that the current valuation level does not offer a sufficient margin of safety and introduces a negative risk-reward skew. This underpins our Underweight rating relative to the peer group.ERDEMIRErdemir continues to trade at a premium to its historical average on normalized EV/EBITDA.The significant investment cycle ahead is likely to continue weighing on FCF, we believe, eroding equity value and increasing financial leverage, absent a steep recovery in prices/margins.

CompanyRating &amp; PTKey pointsACERINOXOW€12.00·Acerinox offers the most resilient near-term earnings profile among peers, via its outsized US exposure and high-margin alloys business.·We see attractive growth prospects via US expansion and Alloys through the Haynes acquisition.·Focus on deleveraging following the Haynes acquisition limits excess shareholder returns for the next couple of years.·Valuation remains attractive vs the stock's own history, and at a discount to alloy peers.·We see longer-term re-rating prospects from the rising alloys share.aperamEW€27.00·Aperam boasts a diversified business model (Brazil, recycling, value add products), but Europe's lacklustre demand prospects are likely to continue to weigh on earnings momentum, in our view, and hinder a near-term re-rating.·Reinvestment drive (Leadership Journey) should underpin earnings growth over the medium term.·FCF profile from 2026 looks compelling on the moderating capex profile, but buybacks are not on the cards until deleveraging is complete (2027, on our estimates).·Valuation is reasonable versus the stock's own history.outokumpuUW€3.00·YID re-rating is overdone, in our view, as near-term earnings momentum lags peers due to the absence of exposure beyond stainless.·We see potential upside to the capex trajectory, following the new strategy announced at the CMD in June.·The stock no longer appears cheap relative to peers, on our numbers.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Equal- weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Not- Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.
In- Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.
Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub- regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
